Award.AwardTitle: Sensitivity of the midlatitude waveguide to the dynamics and observations of Arctic tropopause-based vortices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Heating due to infrared radiation is a great source of uncertainty in weather and climate prediction models, and high impact weather events are often strongly influenced by sub-synoptic-scale features that affect such heating. This proposal will closely examine specific processes active within tropopause polar vortices (TPVs) before they encounter the jet stream. Improved knowledge gained through detailed analysis of the processes, and their interactions with the jet stream, will lead to improvements in weather and climate prediction by improving their representation in numerical models. TPVs are unique because they can exist for long periods of time before affecting the jet stream, and are therefore a key feature to observe and accurately represent.

The principal investigator will develop human capacity and teach students how to advance science through the entire spectrum of research. Quality-controlled datasets, developed during the course of the research, will be made openly available to the research community for use as a long-term tool for predictability studies.

The proposed work would test the hypothesis: diabatic heating from radiation, coupled with weak deformation, is required to maintain the structure of tropopause polar vortices (TPVs) as they encounter increasing vertical shear associated with the waveguide. The project will use three approaches: (1) analyzing the statistical characteristics of TPVs based upon downstream impact, (2) isolating and identifying important physical processes important for TPV development and maintaining TPV intensity as they approach the waveguide through controlled numerical modeling experiments, and (3) diagnosing key uncertainties to identify specific methods of improving process representation in numerical models. Experiments will be conducted using the atmospheric version of the Model for Prediction Across Scales (MPAS) and parallel simulations using the Advanced Weather Research and Forecasting (ARW) model with the Data Assimilation Research Testbed (DART).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Heating due to infrared radiation is a great source of uncertainty in weather and climate prediction models, and high impact weather events are often strongly influenced by sub-synoptic-scale features that affect such heating. This project closely examined specific processes active within tropopause polar vortices (TPVs) before they encountered the jet stream.  TPVs are unique because they can exist for long periods of time before affecting the jet stream and are therefore a key feature to observe and accurately represent.  This study produced a new scientific tool for polar-process studies using the Model for the Prediction Across Scales (MPAS) and Data Assimilation Research Testbed (DART). This global atmospheric modeling and data assimilation system can be used to study polar weather and climate processes as well as the remote influence of polar processes outside of polar regions. 

Three areas of research focus were: (1) the statistical characteristics of TPVs before encountering the jet stream, (2) isolating and identifying important physical processes important for TPV development and maintaining TPV intensity as they approach the waveguide through controlled numerical modeling experiments, and (3) the diagnosis of key uncertainties to identify specific methods of improving process representation in numerical models.  

Cloud and atmospheric state observations from Summit Station, Greenland, combined with temperature and humidity profiles from reanalysis data showed that clouds can sometimes be influential in the intensification of a TPV, but that vertical gradients of clear-sky positive radiative heating rates are more consistently important for the strengthening of TPVs.  Modeling experiments using data from a special aircraft campaign in the North Atlantic Ocean that sampled a merging of a TPV into the jet stream revealed significant model biases in the structure of this merging, and that observations have significant impacts in representing an accurate mesoscale structure of a TPV.  This study also found a relationship between TPVs with extreme weather in the middle latitudes such as cold air outbreaks in North America. Results showed that TPVs associated with cold air outbreaks are likely to form and diabatically intensify in the Arctic on a relatively slow time scale, then rapidly eject equatorward into lower latitudes through preferred pathways to cause extreme cold air outbreaks. A common theme throughout this study is the confirmation that moisture gradients in the upper troposphere and lower stratosphere regions of the atmosphere are very important in order to represent accurate TPV characterization and intensification processes, and that reliable observations of moisture may not be routinely available for weather and climate models to reproduce important TPV characteristics that can impact downstream high impact events. 

This study developed human capacity to teach students how to advance science through the entire spectrum of research.  One undergraduate student, two master?s students, and one doctoral student benefited directly from this research.  Students were recipients of several awards, ranging from student presentation awards at professional conferences and international travel funding to an NSF graduate Fellowship and ASP NCAR postdoctoral fellowship.  Quality-controlled datasets developed during the course of this research can be used by the research community as well as for educational purposes for use as a long-term tool for predictability studies.  Improved understanding of the dynamical processes in the Arctic atmosphere have potential to impact climate and of cryosphere studies of sea and continental ice and perhaps atmospheric chemistry and biological studies of this region.

Finally, this study laid the groundwork for future mesoscale atmospheric studies in the Arctic.  As one example, TPVs are important precursors to Arctic cyclones and to their subsequent evolution.  Arctic cyclones are longer-lived than most extratropical surface cyclones in middle latitudes and can grow into some of the largest storm systems on the planet. Unfortunately, very few direct observations of TPVs are routinely available due to their location over data-sparse regions of the Arctic atmosphere and because of their relatively small spatial scales. While the extent to which sea ice conditions feedback on the atmosphere and TPVs and Arctic cyclones is still unknown, this research has set up a framework for future observation studies that can be used to advance this knowledge.
